SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

com.versant.fund
Interface Handle

All Known Subinterfaces:
ClassHandle
public interface Handle

Handles represent persistent objects in the VERSANT database used in a Session. Database operations that act on a specific object are encapsulated in the interface. There is a Session reference inside every Handle. The Handle must only be used in that session.

Database objects can also be represented by a LOID as a dotted decimal triple e.g. "23.0.1066") or by a LOID represented as an array of eight bytes.

A Handle may also be "empty", representing no database object (i.e. the null LOID, or "0.0.0").

Handles are almost immutable; the subclass ClassHandle that represents a class object in the database is mutable under certain conditions, and the transparent binding classes may have mutable handles internally.

Method Detail

session

Session session()
Returns the session from inside the Handle

isEmpty

boolean isEmpty()
Returns true if this handle references a null database object and otherwise returns false.

The LOID of a null database object is (0.0.0).

asByteArray

byte[] asByteArray()
Converts the handle for this object into a byte-array representation of its LOID.

A VERSANT LOID is expressed as a "dotted decimal triple," such as 2049.0.1042, or for the VERSANT null LOID, 0.0.0.

See Also:
Handle.asString(), Session.newHandle(byte[])

asString

java.lang.String asString()
Converts the handle for this object into a string representation of its LOID.

A VERSANT LOID is expressed as a "dotted decimal triple" in parentheses, such as (2049.0.1042), or for the VERSANT null LOID, (0.0.0).

See Also:
Handle.asByteArray(), Session.newHandle(String)

asLong

long asLong()
Convert the handle to a long value.

isClassObject

boolean isClassObject()
Returns true if this object is a database class object and otherwise returns false.

isInstanceOf

boolean isInstanceOf(java.lang.String classname,
                     boolean canInherit)
Returns true if the given object is an instance of the class specified as classname and otherwise returns false.

If the inheritance flag canInherit is set to true, then this method also returns true if the given object is an instance of a subclass of the given class.

To use this method, you must be connected to the database in which the class is defined.

Parameters:
classname - The name of the class to check.
canInherit - The inheritance flag.

classNameOf

java.lang.String classNameOf()
Returns the class name of the database instance.

classObjectOf

ClassHandle classObjectOf()
Returns a handle to the class object of this instance object.

deleteObject

void deleteObject()
Deletes this persistent object from both memory and the database.

You must be connected to the database that contains the object. The deletion is not persistent until committed.

locateObject

void locateObject(int lockmode)
Fetch object to VERSANT front-end object cache with specified lockmode.

Alternatives for lockmode are:

  • Constants.WLOCK : Write lock
  • Constants.RIWLOCK : Read/intention-write lock
  • Constants.IWLOCK : Intention-write lock
  • Constants.ULOCK : Update lock
  • Constants.RLOCK : Read lock
  • Constants.IRLOCK : Intention-read lock
  • Constants.NOLOCK : No lock
For a complete description of lock modes, see the VERSANT Database Fundamentals.

Parameters:
lockmode - The lock mode with which to fetch the object.

hashKey

int hashKey()
Returns a hash key for this object based on the object's LOID.

Using hashKey() enables you to build in-memory hash tables keyed on object identity.

isEqObject

boolean isEqObject(Handle that)
Returns true if this object and the object specified as that are the same object, otherwise returns false.

Parameters:
that - The name of the object to compare to this object.

compareObject

int compareObject(Handle that)
Compares logical object identifiers.

This method compares the LOID of this object and the object specified as that, and returns zero if the objects are the same object, a positive number if the identifier of this object is greater than the identifier of that object, and a negative number if the identifier of this object is less than the identifier of that object.

The compareObject() method defines a total ordering for all objects. This ordering enables you to maintain ordered sets of objects or to build your own index structures on objects. The ordering implies no other semantics.

Parameters:
that - The object to compare with this object.
See Also:
Handle.hashKey(), Handle.isEqObject(Handle that)

compareTo

int compareTo(Handle that)

releaseObject

void releaseObject()
Immediately releases the memory space used by this object.

This method releases the specified object even if the object is pinned or dirty. It should be used when you have no further use for an object in the current transaction.

All changes made to the object since the last time it was written to the server are dropped. An object may have been written by VERSANT during a transaction due to object swapping, a group write, or a query.

Since VERSANT writes objects per its needs for memory rather than per programming logic, this means that the final state of the object may be uncertain if you have changed it before calling releaseObject(). Thus, if you have changed the object and you want the changes to be written to the database at the next commit, you should write the object before releasing it. See groupWriteObjects().

See Also:
HandleVector.releaseObjects(int)

refreshObject

void refreshObject(int lockmode)
Updates this object in the object memory cache with the current state of the object in its source database and sets the lock described in the combined lock mode lockmode on the object.

Options for lockmode are:

  • Constants.WLOCK : Write lock
  • Constants.RIWLOCK : Read/intention-write lock
  • Constants.IWLOCK : Intention-write lock
  • Constants.ULOCK : Update lock
  • Constants.RLOCK : Read lock
  • Constants.IRLOCK : Intention-read lock
  • Constants.NOLOCK : No lock
If this object is not currently in memory, it is found and pinned in memory.

For a complete description of lock modes, see the VERSANT Database Fundamentals.

Parameters:
lockmode - The mode for the lock.
See Also:
HandleVector.refreshObjects(String, int)

unpinObject

void unpinObject()
Clears any pins on this object that have been set in the current pin region.

If this object is not pinned in another pin region, after this method is called it becomes available for swapping back to its database. Whether or not it is actually removed from memory and returned to its database depends upon available virtual memory and internal VERSANT logic. When you unpin an object, handles remain valid.

Unpinning an object does not abandon any changes made to the object, and regardless of its location, all transaction safeguards of object integrity still apply after an object has been unpinned.

upgradeLockTo

void upgradeLockTo(int lockmode,
                   int options)
Upgrades the lock on this object to the specified lockmode and options.

The available options for lockmode are:

  • Constants.WLOCK : Write lock
  • Constants.RIWLOCK : Read/intention-write lock
  • Constants.IWLOCK : Intention-write lock
  • Constants.ULOCK : Update lock
  • Constants.RLOCK : Read lock
  • Constants.IRLOCK : Intention-read lock
  • Constants.NOLOCK : No lock
Alternatives for options are:

  • Constants.LK_IMPPROMOTE: Implicitly promote the lock.
  • Constants.LK_NOWAIT: Returns immediately if the lock is not granted.

The default is to try until time-out occurs if the lock is not granted. The length of the time-out period is determined by the value of the server process parameter lock_wait_timeout in the database server profile file profile.be.

If the requested lock mode is weaker than the currently held lock mode, no changes are made. If the requested lock mode is neither stronger nor weaker than the currently held lock mode, then a lock mode that is stronger than both the requested lock mode and the currently held lock mode is acquired.

If a lock is acquired on an instance of a class, an intention lock of the same strength is implicitly acquired on the class object if the instance lock mode is compatible with an intention read lock in the prevailing lock model, otherwise, an intention write lock is implicitly acquired on the class object.

If not successful, one of the following errors are returned: SM_LOCK_WOULDBLOCK, SM_LOCK_DEADLOCK, SM_LOCK_TIMEDOUT, SM_LOCK_NOUPGRADE, SM_LOCK_INVALID, SM_TR_COMPATIBILITY, ACT_NO_ACTIVITY, or OB_NO_SUCH_OBJECT.

For a complete description of lock modes, see the VERSANT Database Fundamentals.

Parameters:
lockmode - The lock mode.
options - Method options.
See Also:
HandleVector.downgradeLocksTo(int)

downgradeLockTo

void downgradeLockTo(int lockmode)
Downgrades the lock on this object to the lock mode lockmode.

Alternatives for lockmode are:

  • Constants.WLOCK : Write lock
  • Constants.RIWLOCK : Read/intention-write lock
  • Constants.IWLOCK : Intention-write lock
  • Constants.ULOCK : Update lock
  • Constants.RLOCK : Read lock
  • Constants.IRLOCK : Intention-read lock
  • Constants.NOLOCK : No lock
To release a lock, set the lock mode to NOLOCK.

If the specified lockmode is stronger than or not comparable to the currently held lock mode, no downgrading occurs.

The lock on the class object for the receiver is not downgraded.

If locks are downgraded on modified objects, the ability of the transaction to rollback may be jeopardized.

If not successful, one of the following errors is returned: OB_NULL, OB_BADLOCK, or OB_NO_SUCH_OBJECT.

For a complete description of lock modes, see the VERSANT Database Fundamentals Manual.

Parameters:
lockmode - The lock mode to associate with this instance.
See Also:
Handle.upgradeLockTo(int lockmode, int options), HandleVector.downgradeLocksTo(int)

findRemoteObject

java.lang.String findRemoteObject(java.lang.String[] dbnames)
Returns the database name of the database that contains this object.

If the object is already in the cache, the database name is obtained from its cached object descriptor (cod). Otherwise, if no database names are given in dbnames[], first the session database and then all currently connected group databases are searched. Specifying dbnames[] for the search improves performance.

Parameters:
dbnames - The names of all the database to search.

isCached

boolean isCached()
Returns true if the object corresponding to this handle is in the object cache (C cache).

Returns true if this object is marked for deletion at the next commit and otherwise returns false.

boolean isDirty()
Returns true if this object is marked as dirty and otherwise returns false.

isSchema

boolean isSchema()
Returns true if this object is a class (schema) object and otherwise returns false.

isPinned

boolean isPinned()
Returns true if this object has been pinned in the object cache and otherwise returns false.

markModified

void markModified()
Prepares this object for modification by setting a short write lock and marking it dirty.

This method is normally used after you have retrieved an object for inspection and pinned it in read mode with get(). Because it sets a write lock, you should be prepared to handle lock contention errors.

Only objects marked as dirty are sent to their database at the next commit. The requirement to mark as dirty those objects that have been changed significantly increases performance as it avoids VERSANT having to compare each object with its stored state at the time of a commit or to send more changes than necessary to the server.

You do not need to call this function if you use put(), putAscii(), or putObject() to change the value of an attribute, since these methods set a write lock and mark the object as dirty.

unmarkModified

void unmarkModified()
Marks an object as clean.

See Also:
Handle.markModified()

getAscii

java.lang.String getAscii(Attr attr)
Gets a representation of the value of the attribute expressed as a string of characters from the US-ASCII subset (Unicode characters 32 through 126).

The representation is designed to be human-readable and natural, as might be displayed and edited in a browser. The default representation is set by the appropriate convertTypeToAscii() method, where Type is the data type involved. You can override the default behavior by implementing your own policy.

You can use the string returned by getAscii() in putAscii() to set the value of an attribute.

The pre-defined convertTypeToAscii() methods are:

  • convertBooleanToAscii()
  • convertBooleanArrayToAscii()
  • convertByteToAscii()
  • convertByteArrayToAscii()
  • convertDoubleToAscii()
  • convertDoubleArrayToAscii()
  • convertFloatToAscii()
  • convertFloatArrayToAscii()
  • convertHandleToAscii()
  • convertHandleArrayToAscii()
  • convertIntToAscii()
  • convertIntArrayToAscii()
  • convertStringToAscii()

Parameters:
attr - The name of the attribute class.
See Also:
Handle.putAscii(Attr,String)

putAscii

void putAscii(Attr attr,
              java.lang.String str)
Puts the value of the attribute attr from a string str of the same representation as returned by getAscii().

Before setting the attribute value, putAscii() acquires a write lock on the object and marks it dirty.

You can override the pre-defined conversion methods by implementing your own policy.

The pre-defined convertTypeToAscii() methods are:

  • convertBooleanToAscii()
  • convertBooleanArrayToAscii()
  • convertByteToAscii()
  • convertByteArrayToAscii()
  • convertDoubleToAscii()
  • convertDoubleArrayToAscii()
  • convertFloatToAscii()
  • convertFloatArrayToAscii()
  • convertHandleToAscii()
  • convertHandleArrayToAscii()
  • convertIntToAscii()
  • convertIntArrayToAscii()
  • convertStringToAscii()

Parameters:
attr - The name of the attribute class.
str - The ASCII name specified for storage of the attribute value.
See Also:
Handle.getAscii(Attr)

getObject

java.lang.Object getObject(Attr attr)
Gets the value represented by an attribute of a Java object, using standard Java classes such as Boolean, Integer, Float, Double, String and the array classes.

The pre-defined convertTypeToObject() methods are:

  • convertBooleanToAscii()
  • convertBooleanArrayToAscii()
  • convertByteToAscii()
  • convertByteArrayToAscii()
  • convertDoubleToAscii()
  • convertDoubleArrayToAscii()
  • convertFloatToAscii()
  • convertFloatArrayToAscii()
  • convertHandleToAscii()
  • convertHandleArrayToAscii()
  • convertIntToAscii()
  • convertIntArrayToAscii()
  • convertStringToAscii()

Parameters:
attr - The name of the attribute class.
See Also:
Handle.putObject(Attr,Object)

putObject

void putObject(Attr attr,
               java.lang.Object obj)
Puts the value into the attribute attr from the object obj, as returned by the getObject() method.

Before setting the attribute value, putObject() acquires a write lock on the object and marks it dirty.

Parameters:
attr - The name of the attribute class.
obj - The name of the object.
See Also:
Handle.getObject(Attr)

handleToObject

java.lang.Object handleToObject()
Convert a Handle to a persistent object for the transparent layer.

hashCode

int hashCode()
Returns a hash code value for the object.

The general contract of the hashCode() method, that is defined for every Java object is:

Whenever it is invoked on the same object more than once during an execution of a JVI application, the hashCode() method must consistently return the same integer. This integer need not remain consistent from one execution of an application to another execution of the same application.

If two objects are equal according to the equals method, then calling the hashCode() method on each of the two objects must produce the same integer result.

The hashCode() method for a Handle instance modifies this contract. The hashCode() method returns the same value for two different Handle instances, if the Handle refers to a persistent object. This hashCode value will be the same across different executions of the JVI application.

Overrides:
hashCode in class java.lang.Object
See Also:
Handle.equals(Object)

equals

boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
Compares two handle objects for equality.

The equivalence is based on a check for two handle objects being in the same database session with the same cache entries. Note that two handle objects with the same hashCode need not be equal if they are in different sessions. However, two handle objects that are equal will have the same hashCode as they would represent the same persistent object.

Overrides:
equals in class java.lang.Object
Parameters:
obj - The object to compare.
See Also:
Handle.hashCode()
